importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the AWS outage reported in the article, highlighting a recent global internet disruption that underscores ongoing vulnerabilities in cloud infrastructure.
The date of the previous major AWS outage, indicating a pattern of service disruptions and a growing concern about the reliability of cloud computing platforms.
The date of the CrowdStrike software glitch that caused a global IT outage, used as a comparative example of how a single technical failure can have widespread consequences.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which the AWS outage occurred and was resolved, illustrating the duration and impact of a major internet service disruption.

keyTakeAways: The internet's reliance on a small number of cloud providers, such as AWS, makes it vulnerable to outages when a single component fails.
DNS failures — like those affecting AWS's Domain Name System — can disconnect services from their data, even if data is safely stored.
Outages are not necessarily due to cyberattacks but often stem from technical faults, such as faulty updates or misconfigurations in cloud infrastructure.
The frequency of major outages suggests a lack of redundancy and diversification in how companies manage their digital services.
The 2024 CrowdStrike incident and AT&T’s 2024 network outages show that global disruptions from single-point failures are not rare, emphasizing systemic risks in digital infrastructure.
AWS services, such as DynamoDB and EC2, are central to many online applications, meaning a failure in one service can cascade across multiple websites and apps.

namedEntities.name: Amazon Web Services (AWS)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A cloud computing platform that hosts critical online services including banking, social media, shopping, and airline booking sites.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: AWS is central to the functioning of the modern internet, and its outage disrupted millions of services worldwide, highlighting systemic fragility in digital infrastructure.

namedEntities.name: Domain Name System (DNS)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A system that translates human-readable web addresses (e.g., amazon.com) into machine-readable IP addresses.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The DNS failure caused websites hosted on AWS to become inaccessible, demonstrating how a core internet infrastructure component can disrupt global services.

namedEntities.name: DynamoDB
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A database service hosted by AWS that stores customer and other critical data for numerous companies.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The inability of customers to access data in DynamoDB during the outage shows how a failure in a core data service can isolate online applications from their data.

namedEntities.name: EC2
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A virtual server service used by companies to build and run online applications on AWS.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The disruption of EC2 services indicates that even foundational computing resources on AWS were affected, amplifying the scale of the outage.

namedEntities.name: CrowdStrike
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A cybersecurity software company that provides cloud-based endpoint protection and software updates.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Its 2024 software glitch caused a global IT outage, serving as a historical precedent for how a single update can cascade into widespread disruption.

namedEntities.name: AT&T
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major telecommunications company whose network experienced multiple outages, including an 11-hour meltdown.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: AT&T’s network failures demonstrate how infrastructure failures in telecom can disrupt digital workforces and remote labor, reinforcing the fragility of digital services.

namedEntities.name: Rob Jardin
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Chief digital officer at cybersecurity firm NymVPN.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He provided expert commentary on the AWS outage, suggesting it was a technical fault rather than a cyberattack, and emphasized the internet's centralized risks.

namedEntities.name: Mike Chapple
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Cybersecurity expert and IT professor at the University of Notre Dame.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He offered expert analysis on the impact and visibility of AWS outages, explaining why such events receive so much attention due to their global scale and disruption.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Amazon Web Services (AWS) experienced a significant global outage on October 20, 2025, lasting several hours, which disrupted major online services such as banking, social media, shopping, and airline booking. The root cause was traced to a failure in AWS’s Domain Name System (DNS), preventing websites from accessing data stored in DynamoDB and other services like EC2. Although AWS is generally reliable, experts note that the internet’s heavy dependence on a few cloud providers makes it vulnerable to cascading failures. This incident mirrors past large-scale outages, such as the 2024 CrowdStrike software glitch and AT&T’s network failures, highlighting a broader systemic issue: the lack of redundancy and decentralization in modern digital infrastructure. Experts emphasize that while AWS operates at scale, the absence of fallback systems and competition in cloud computing increases the risk of widespread disruption.
title: The internet just had another global outage. Why does this keep happening?
